title: Structure and functionality
text: unitquantreg R package provide efficient tools estimation inference parametric quantile regression models bounded data. current version unitquantreg 11 probability distributions available user choice. Table lists families distributions, abbreviations paper reference. Available families distributions abbreviations reference. [dpqr]’s functions distributions vectorized implemented C++. log likelihood, score hessian functions also implemented C++ order guarantee computational efficiency. parameter estimation inference performed frequentist paradigm. Maximization log-likelihood function done optimization techniques available R optimx package, general-purpose optimization wrapper function allows use several R tools optimization, including existing stats::optim() function. achieve quick better convergence analytical score function use maximization. Also, standard errors parameter estimates computed using analytical hessian matrix.

title: Structure and functionality
text: unitquantreg package built around unitquantreg() function perform fit parametric quantile regression models via likelihood method. unitquantreg() function standard arguments stats::glm() function, follows: formula argument use concept Formula package allows multiple parts right-hand side, indicates regression structure quantile shape parameter distribution. instance, formula = y ~ x1 | z1 means following regression structure \[ g_1(\mu) = \beta_0 + \beta_1\,x_1 \quad \textrm{} \quad g_2(\theta) = \gamma_0 + \gamma_1\,z_1 \] \(\mu\) indicates quantile order \(\tau\) \(\theta\) shape parameter. tau argument indicates quantile(s) estimated, possible specify vector quantiles. family argument specify distribution family using abbreviation dpqr functions, listed Table . control argument controls fitting process unitquantreg.control() function returned list default values : two important arguments hessian gradient tell optimx::optimx() whether use numerical hessian matrix analytical score vector, respectively. , hessian = TRUE, standard errors computed using numerical hessian matrix. detailed description arguments see package documentation.
code: #> function (formula, data, subset, na.action, tau, family, link = c("logit",  #>     "probit", "cloglog", "cauchit"), link.theta = c("identity",  #>     "log", "sqrt"), start = NULL, control = unitquantreg.control(),  #>     model = TRUE, x = FALSE, y = TRUE)  #> NULL unlist(unitquantreg.control()) #>                 method                hessian               gradient  #>                 "BFGS"                "FALSE"                 "TRUE"  #>                  maxit                 reltol                  factr  #>                 "5000" "1.49011611938477e-08"                "1e+07"  #>                  trace                 dowarn             starttests  #>                    "0"                "FALSE"                "FALSE"  #>                fnscale  #>                    "1"

title: Structure and functionality
text: unitquanreg() function returns object class unitquanreg argument tau scalar unitquanregs tau vector. currently methods implemented unitquantreg objects : unitquantregs objects important mention unitquantregs objects consists list unitquantreg objects according vector tau. Furthermore, package provide functions designated model comparison uniquantreg objects. Particularly, likelihood_stats() function computes likelihood-based statistics (Neg2LogLike, AIC, BIC HQIC), vuong.test() function performs Vuong test two fitted non nested models, pairwise.vuong.test() function performs pairwise Vuong test adjusted p-value according stats::p.adjust.methods fitted models Finally, uniquantreg objects also permits use inference methods functions lmtest::coeftest(), lmtest::coefci, lmtest::coefci, lmtest::waldtest lmtest::lrtest implemented lmtest perform hypothesis test, confidence intervals nested models. Next, detailed account usage functions provided.
code: methods(class = "unitquantreg") #>  [1] coef         confint      fitted       hnp          logLik       #>  [6] model.frame  model.matrix plot         predict      print        #> [11] residuals    summary      terms        update       vcov         #> see '?methods' for accessing help and source code methods(class = "unitquantregs") #> [1] plot    print   summary #> see '?methods' for accessing help and source code

title: Structure and functionality
text: Mazucheli et al. (2020) consider data set related access people households piped water supply cities Brazil Southeast Northeast regions. response variable phpws proportion households piped water supply. covariates : mhdi: human development index. incpc: per capita income. region: 0 southeast, 1 northeast. pop: population. Assuming following regression structure parameters: \[ \textrm{logit}(\mu_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \texttt{mhdi}_{i1} + \beta_2 \texttt{incp}_{i2} + \beta_3 \texttt{region}_{i3} + \beta_4 \log\left(\texttt{pop}_{i4}\right), \] \[ \log(\theta_i) = \gamma_0. \] \(= 1, \ldots, 3457\).

title: Structure and functionality
text: \(\tau = 0.5\), , median regression model fitted families distributions follows:

title: Structure and functionality
text: Let’s check likelihood-based statistics fit According statistics unit-Logistic, Johnson-SB, unit-Burr-XII unit-Weibull best models. Now, let’s perform pairwise vuong test check statistical significant difference four models. adjusted p-values pairwise Vuong tests shows large statistical significance difference models. particular, pairwise comparison unit-Logistic models provide smaller p-values, indicating unit-Logistic median regression model suitable model data set comparing others families distributions.
code: likelihood_stats(lt = lt_fits) #>  #>  Likelihood-based statistics of fit for unit quantile regression models  #>  #> Call:  likelihood_stats(lt = lt_fits) #>  #>                                    Neg2LogLike AIC       BIC       HQIC      #> unit-Logistic                      -8443.029   -8431.029 -8394.140 -8417.855 #> Johnson-SB                         -8238.405   -8226.405 -8189.516 -8213.232 #> unit-Burr-XII                      -8096.114   -8084.114 -8047.225 -8070.941 #> unit-Weibull                       -7994.077   -7982.077 -7945.188 -7968.903 #> unit-Birnbaum-Saunders             -7955.990   -7943.990 -7907.101 -7930.817 #> unit-Gompertz                      -7808.838   -7796.838 -7759.949 -7783.664 #> arc-secant hyperbolic Weibull      -7679.482   -7667.482 -7630.593 -7654.308 #> log-extended Exponential-Geometric -7677.034   -7665.034 -7628.145 -7651.860 #> unit-Generalized Half-Normal-E     -7496.966   -7484.966 -7448.077 -7471.792 #> Kumaraswamy                        -7188.498   -7176.498 -7139.609 -7163.324 #> unit-Chen                          -7016.542   -7004.542 -6967.653 -6991.368 #> unit-Generalized Half-Normal-X     -6965.962   -6953.962 -6917.073 -6940.789 #> unit-Gumbel                        -6531.775   -6519.775 -6482.886 -6506.602 lt_chosen <- lt_fits[c("unit-Logistic", "Johnson-SB", "unit-Burr-XII", "unit-Weibull")] pairwise.vuong.test(lt = lt_chosen) #>  #>  Pairwise comparisons using Vuong likelihood ratio test for non-nested models  #>  #> data:  unitquantreg(formula = phpws ~ mhdi + incpc + region + log(pop),  #>     data = water, tau = 0.5, family = fam, link = "logit", link.theta = "log")  #>  #>               unit-Logistic Johnson-SB unit-Burr-XII #> Johnson-SB    0.00031       -          -             #> unit-Burr-XII 3.9e-07       0.09659    -             #> unit-Weibull  8.8e-11       0.00013    0.04868       #>  #> P value adjustment method: holm

title: Structure and functionality
text: possible check model assumptions diagnostic plots using plot() function method unitquantreg objects. residuals() method provides quantile, cox-snell, working partial residuals type. randomize quantile residuals default choice plot() method.  Plots residuals fitted linear predictor residuals indices observations tools diagnostic analysis check structural form model. Two features plots important: Trends: trends appearing plots indicate systematic component can improved. mean changing link function, adding extra explanatory variables, transforming explanatory variables. Constant variation: random component correct variance points approximately constant. Working residuals versus linear predictor used check possible misspecification link function Half-normal plot residuals check distribution assumption. Another best practice diagnostic analysis inspect (Half)-Normal plots simulated envelope several quantile value. done obtain robust evaluation model assumptions. Thus, let’s fit unit-Logistic quantile regression model various quantiles. Now, can check (Half)-Normal plots using output hnp() method.
code: oldpar <- par(no.readonly = TRUE) par(mfrow = c(2, 2)) plot(lt_fits[["unit-Logistic"]]) par(oldpar) system.time(   fits_ulogistic <- unitquantreg(formula = phpws ~ mhdi + incpc + region + log(pop),                                  data = water, tau = 1:49/50,                                  family = "ulogistic", link = "logit",                                  link.theta = "log")) #>    user  system elapsed  #>  13.071   0.001  13.071 library(ggplot2) get_data <- function(obj) {   tmp <- hnp(obj, halfnormal = FALSE, plot = FALSE, nsim = 10)   tmp <- as.data.frame(do.call("cbind", tmp))   tmp$tau <- as.character(obj$tau)   tmp } chosen_taus <- c("0.02", "0.5", "0.98") df_plot <- do.call("rbind", lapply(fits_ulogistic[chosen_taus], get_data)) df_plot$tau <- paste0(expression(tau), " == ", df_plot$tau)  ggplot(df_plot, aes(x = teo, y = obs)) +   facet_wrap(~tau, labeller = label_parsed) +   geom_point(shape = 3, size = 1.4) +   geom_line(aes(y = median), linetype = "dashed") +   geom_line(aes(y = lower), col = "#0080ff") +   geom_line(aes(y = upper), col = "#0080ff") +   theme_bw() +   labs(x = "Theoretical quantiles", y = "Randomized quantile residuals") +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-3, 3, by = 1)) +   scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(-3, 3, by = 1)) +   theme_bw() +   theme(text = element_text(size = 16, family = "Palatino"),          panel.grid.minor = element_blank())

title: Structure and functionality
text: Inference results parameter estimates can accessed summary method. instance, unitquantregs objects plot method provide convenience check significance well effect estimate along specify quantile value.  Curiously, unit-Logistic quantile regression models capture constant effect covariates along different quantiles. contrast, unit-Weibull model (fourth best model) found decrease effect mhdi covaraite response quantile increases increase effects incpc region response variable quantile increases.  Using plot() method argument = "conddist" unitquantregs objects possible estimate visualize conditional distribution response variable different values covariates. instance,
code: summary(lt_fits[["unit-Logistic"]]) #>  #>  Wald-tests for unit-Logistic quantile regression model #>  #> Call:  unitquantreg(formula = phpws ~ mhdi + incpc + region + log(pop),  #>     data = water, tau = 0.5, family = fam, link = "logit", link.theta = "log") #>  #> Mu coefficients: (quantile model with logit link and tau = 0.5):  #>               Estimate Std. Error Z value Pr(>|z|)     #> (Intercept) -5.3654690  0.3373263 -15.906  < 2e-16 *** #> mhdi        10.5080995  0.5717793  18.378  < 2e-16 *** #> incpc        0.0015596  0.0001706   9.140  < 2e-16 *** #> region      -0.1582600  0.0488825  -3.238  0.00121 **  #> log(pop)     0.0177337  0.0167306   1.060  0.28917     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Model with constant shape: #>            Estimate Std. Error Z value Pr(>|z|)     #> log(theta)  0.63006    0.01421   44.35   <2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual degrees of freedom: 3451 #> Log-likelihood: 4221.514 #> Number of iterations: 65 plot(fits_ulogistic, which = "coef") system.time(   fits_uweibull <- unitquantreg(formula = phpws ~ mhdi + incpc + region + log(pop),                                  data = water, tau = 1:49/50,                                  family = "uweibull", link = "logit",                                  link.theta = "log")) #>    user  system elapsed  #>  14.512   0.004  14.519 plot(fits_uweibull, which = "coef") lt_data <- list(mhdi = c(0.5, 0.7), incpc = round(mean(water$incpc)),                 region = c(1, 0), pop = round(mean(water$pop))) plot(fits_ulogistic, which = "conddist", at_obs = lt_data, at_avg = FALSE,      dist_type = "density") plot(fits_ulogistic, which = "conddist", at_obs = lt_data, at_avg = FALSE,      dist_type = "cdf")

title: The arcsecant hyperbolic Weibull distribution — ashw
text: dashw gives density, pashw gives distribution function, qashw gives quantile function rashw generates random deviates. Invalid arguments return error message.

title: The arcsecant hyperbolic Weibull distribution — ashw
text: Probability density function $$f(y;\alpha, \theta)=\frac{\alpha \theta}{y\sqrt{1-y^2}} \mathrm{arcsech}(y)^{\theta-1}\exp\left [ -\alpha \mathrm{arcsech}(y)^\theta \right ]$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y;\alpha, \theta)=\exp\left [ -\alpha \mathrm{arcsech}(y)^\theta \right ]$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau;\alpha, \theta)= \mathrm{sech}\left \{ \left [ -\alpha^{-1} \log(\tau)\right ]^{\frac{1}{\theta}} \right \}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha = g^{-1}(\mu) = -\frac{\log(\tau)}{\mathrm{arcsech}(\mu)^\theta}$$ \(\theta >0\) shape parameter \(\mathrm{arcsech}(y)= \log\left[\left( 1+\sqrt{1-y^2} \right)/y \right]\).

title: The arcsecant hyperbolic Weibull distribution — ashw
text: Korkmaz, M. C., Chesneau, C. Korkmaz, Z. S., (2021). new alternative quantile regression model bounded response educational measurements applications OECD countries. Journal Applied Statistics, 1--25.

text: x, q vector positive quantiles. mu location parameter indicating \(\tau\)-th quantile, \(\tau \(0, 1)\). theta nonnegative shape parameter. tau parameter specify quantile used. log, log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). lower.tail logical; TRUE, (default), \(P(X \leq{x})\) returned, otherwise \(P(X > x)\). p vector probabilities. n number observations. length(n) > 1, length taken number required.

title: The Johnson SB distribution — johnsonsb
text: djohnsonsb gives density, pjohnsonsb gives distribution function, qjohnsonsb gives quantile function rjohnsonsb generates random deviates. Invalid arguments return error message.

title: The Johnson SB distribution — johnsonsb
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\theta }{\sqrt{2\pi }}\frac{1}{y(1-y)}\exp\left\{ -\frac{1}{2}\left[\alpha +\theta \log\left(\frac{y}{1-y}\right)\right] ^{2}\right\}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\Phi \left[ \alpha +\theta \log \left( \frac{y}{1-y}\right) \right]$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\exp \left[ \frac{\Phi ^{-1}(\tau)-\alpha }{\theta }\right] }{1+\exp \left[ \frac{\Phi ^{-1}(\tau )-\alpha }{\theta }\right] }$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha =g^{-1}(\mu )=\Phi ^{-1}(\tau )-\theta \log \left( \frac{\mu }{1-\mu }\right)$$

title: The Johnson SB distribution — johnsonsb
text: Lemonte, . J. Bazán, J. L., (2015). New class Johnson SB distributions associated regression model rates proportions. Biometrical Journal, 58(4), 727--746. Johnson, N. L., (1949). Systems frequency curves generated methods translation. Biometrika, 36(1), 149--176.

title: The Kumaraswamy distribution — kum
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\alpha \theta y^{\theta -1}(1-y^{\theta })^{\alpha-1}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=1-\left( 1-y^{\theta }\right) ^{\alpha }$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha ,\theta )=\left[ 1-\left( 1-\tau \right) ^{\frac{1}{\alpha }}\right] ^{\frac{1}{\theta }}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )=\frac{\log (1-\tau )}{\log (1-\mu ^{\theta })}$$

title: The Kumaraswamy distribution — kum

title: The Log-extended exponential-geometric distribution — leeg
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\theta \left( 1+\alpha \right) y^{\theta -1}}{\left( 1+\alpha y^{\theta }\right) ^{2}}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\left( 1+\alpha \right) y^{\theta }}{1+\alpha y^{\theta }}$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha ,\theta )=\left[ \frac{\tau }{1+\alpha \left( 1-\tau\right) }\right] ^{\frac{1}{\theta }}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )=-\frac{1-\tau \mu ^{\theta }}{\left( 1-\tau \right) }$$

title: Likelihood-based statistics of fit for unitquantreg objects. — likelihood_stats
text: Neg2LogLike: log-likelihood reported $$Neg2LogLike= -2\log(L)$$ AIC: Akaike's information criterion (AIC) defined $$AIC = -2\log(L)+2p$$ BIC: Schwarz Bayesian information criterion (BIC) defined $$BIC =  -2\log(L) + p\log(n)$$ HQIC: Hannan Quinn information criterion (HQIC)  defined $$HQIC =  -2\log(L) + 2p\log[\log(n)]$$ \(L\) likelihood function.

title: Residuals method for unitquantreg objects — residuals.unitquantreg
text: residuals method can compute quantile Cox-Snell residuals. residuals defined, respectively, $$r_{Q} = \Phi^{-1}\left[ F(y_i \mid \widehat{\mu}_i, \widehat{\theta}_i)\right]$$ $$r_{CS} = -\log\left[1- F(y_i \mid \widehat{\mu}_i, \widehat{\theta}_i)\right]$$ \(\widehat{\mu}_i\) \(\widehat{\theta}_i\) fitted values parameters \(\mu\) \(\theta\), \(F(\cdot \mid \cdot, \cdot)\) cumulative distribution function (c.d.f.) \(\Phi(\cdot)\) c.d.f. standard Normal distribution. Apart variability due estimates parameters,fitted regression model correctly specified quantile residuals, \(r_Q\), follow standard Normal distribution Cox-Snell residuals, \(r_{CS}\), follow standard exponential distribution.

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
text: Density function, distribution function, quantile function random number generation function unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution reparametrized terms \(\tau\)-th quantile, \(\tau \(0, 1)\).

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
code: dubs(x, mu, theta, tau = 0.5, log = FALSE)  pubs(q, mu, theta, tau = 0.5, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  qubs(p, mu, theta, tau = 0.5, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  rubs(n, mu, theta, tau = 0.5)

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
text: x, q vector positive quantiles. mu location parameter indicating \(\tau\)-th quantile, \(\tau \(0, 1)\). theta nonnegative shape parameter. tau parameter specify quantile used. log, log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). lower.tail logical; TRUE, (default), \(P(X \leq{x})\) returned, otherwise \(P(X > x)\). p vector probabilities. n number observations. length(n) > 1, length taken number required.

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
text: dubs gives density, pubs gives distribution function, qubs gives quantile function rubs generates random deviates. Invalid arguments return error message.

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{1}{2y\alpha \theta \sqrt{2\pi }}\left[\left( -\frac{\alpha }{\log (y)}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}+\left( -\frac{\alpha}{\log (y)}\right) ^{\frac{3}{2}}\right] \exp \left[ \frac{1}{2\theta ^{2}}\left( 2+\frac{\log (y)}{\alpha }+\frac{\alpha }{\log (y)}\right) \right]$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=1-\Phi \left\{ \frac{1}{\theta }\left[ \left( -\frac{\log (y)}{\alpha }\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}-\left( -\frac{\alpha }{\log(y)}\right) ^{\frac{1}{2}}\right] \right\}$$ Quantile function $$Q\left( \tau \mid \alpha ,\theta \right) ={\exp }\left\{ -{\frac{2\alpha}{2+\left[ {\theta }\Phi ^{-1}\left( 1-\tau \right) \right] ^{2}-{\theta } \Phi ^{-1}\left( 1-\tau \right) \sqrt{4+\left[ {\theta }\Phi ^{-1}\left(1-\tau \right) \right] ^{2}}}}\right\}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )=\log \left( \mu \right) g\left( \theta ,\tau \right)$$ \(g\left( \theta ,\tau \right) =-\frac{1}{2}\left\{ 2+\left[ {\theta }\Phi^{-1}\left( 1-\tau \right) \right] ^{2}-{\theta }\Phi ^{-1}\left( 1-\tau\right) \sqrt{4+{\theta }\Phi ^{-1}\left( 1-\tau \right) }\right\} .\)

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
text: Birnbaum, Z. W. Saunders, S. C., (1969). new family life distributions. Journal Applied Probability, 6(2), 637--652. Mazucheli, J., Menezes, . F. B. Dey, S., (2018). unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution applications. Chilean Journal Statistics, 9(1), 47--57. Mazucheli, J., Alves, B. Menezes, . F. B., (2021). new quantile regression modeling bounded data unit Birnbaum-Saunders distribution applications. Simmetry, (), 1--28.

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
text: Josmar Mazucheli jmazucheli@gmail.com André F. B. Menezes andrefelipemaringa@gmail.com

title: The unit-Birnbaum-Saunders distribution — ubs
code: set.seed(123) x <- rubs(n = 1000, mu = 0.5, theta = 1.5, tau = 0.5) R <- range(x) S <- seq(from = R[1], to = R[2], by =  0.01) hist(x, prob = TRUE, main = 'unit-Birnbaum-Saunders') lines(S, dubs(x = S, mu = 0.5, theta = 1.5, tau = 0.5), col = 2)  plot(ecdf(x)) lines(S, pubs(q = S, mu = 0.5, theta = 1.5, tau = 0.5), col = 2)  plot(quantile(x, probs = S), type = "l") lines(qubs(p = S, mu = 0.5, theta = 1.5, tau = 0.5), col = 2)

code: duburrxii(x, mu, theta, tau = 0.5, log = FALSE)  puburrxii(q, mu, theta, tau = 0.5, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  quburrxii(p, mu, theta, tau = 0.5, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  ruburrxii(n, mu, theta, tau = 0.5)

title: The unit-Burr-XII distribution — uburrxii
text: x, q vector positive quantiles. mu location parameter indicating \(\tau\)-th quantile, \(\tau \(0, 1)\). theta nonnegative shape parameter. tau parameter specify quantile used. log, log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). lower.tail logical; TRUE, (default), \(P(X \leq{x})\) returned, otherwise \(P(X > x)\). p vector probabilities. n number observations. length(n) > 1, length taken number required.

title: The unit-Burr-XII distribution — uburrxii
text: duburrxii gives density, puburrxii gives distribution function, quburrxii gives quantile function ruburrxii generates random deviates. Invalid arguments return error message.

title: The unit-Burr-XII distribution — uburrxii
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha, \theta )=\frac{\alpha \theta }{y}\left[ -\log (y)\right]^{\theta -1}\left\{ 1+\left[ -\log (y)\right] ^{\theta }\right\} ^{-\alpha -1}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha, \theta )=\left\{ 1+\left[ -\log (y)\right] ^{\theta}\right\} ^{-\alpha }$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha, \theta )=\exp \left[ -\left( \tau ^{-\frac{1}{\alpha }}-1\right)^{\frac{1}{\theta }} \right]$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu)=\frac{\log\left ( \tau^{-1} \right )}{\log\left [ 1+\log\left ( \frac{1}{\mu} \right )^\theta \right ]}$$

title: The unit-Burr-XII distribution — uburrxii
text: Korkmaz M. C. Chesneau, C., (2021). unit Burr-XII distribution quantile regression modeling applications. Computational Applied Mathematics, 40(29), 1--26.

title: The unit-Chen distribution — uchen
text: x, q vector positive quantiles. mu location parameter indicating \(\tau\)-th quantile, \(\tau \(0, 1)\). theta nonnegative shape parameter. tau parameter specify quantile used. log, log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). lower.tail logical; TRUE, (default), \(P(X \leq{x})\) returned, otherwise \(P(X > x)\). p vector probabilities. n number observations. length(n) > 1, length taken number required.

title: The unit-Chen distribution — uchen
text: duchen gives density, puchen gives distribution function, quchen gives quantile function ruchen generates random deviates. Invalid arguments return error message.

title: The unit-Chen distribution — uchen
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\alpha \theta }{y}\left[ -\log (y)\right]^{\theta -1}\exp \left\{ \left[ -\log \left( y\right) \right]^{\theta}\right\} \exp \left\{ \alpha \left\{ 1-\exp \left[ \left( -\log (y)\right)^{\theta }\right] \right\} \right\}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\exp \left\{ \alpha \left\{ 1-\exp \left[ \left(-\log (y)\right)^{\theta }\right] \right\} \right\}$$ Quantile function $$Q\left( \tau \mid \alpha ,\theta \right) =\exp \left\{ -\left[ \log \left( 1-{\frac{\log \left( \tau \right) }{\alpha }}\right) \right]^{\frac{1}{\theta}}\right\}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )={\frac{\log \left( \tau \right) }{1-\exp \left[ \left( -\log (\mu )\right)^{\theta }\right]}}$$

title: The unit-Chen distribution — uchen
text: Korkmaz, M. C., Emrah, ., Chesneau, C. Yousof, H. M., (2020). unit-Chen distribution associated quantile regression applications. Journal Applied Statistics, 44(1) 1--22.

title: The unit-Half-Normal-E distribution — ughne
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi }}\frac{\theta }{y\left[ -\log\left( y\right) \right] }\left( -{\frac{\log \left( y\right) }{\alpha }} \right)^{\theta }\mathrm{\exp }\left\{ -\frac{1}{2}\left[ -{\frac{\log \left( y\right) }{\alpha }}\right]^{2\theta }\right\}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=2\Phi \left[ -\left( -{\frac{\log \left( y\right) }{\alpha }}\right)^{\theta }\right]$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha ,\theta )=\exp \left\{ -\alpha \left[ -\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{\tau }{2}\right) \right]^{\frac{1}{\theta }}\right\}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )=-\log \left( \mu \right) \left[ -\Phi^{-1}\left( \frac{\tau }{2}\right) \right]^{-\frac{1}{\theta }}$$

title: The unit-Half-Normal-X distribution — ughnx
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi }}\frac{\theta }{y\left(1-y\right) }\left( {\frac{y}{\alpha \left( 1-y\right) }}\right) ^{\theta }\mathrm{\exp }\left\{ -\frac{1}{2}\left[ {\frac{y}{\alpha \left( 1-y\right) }}\right] ^{2\theta }\right\}$$ Cumulative density function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=2\Phi \left[ \left( \frac{y}{\alpha \left(1-y\right) }\right) ^{\theta }\right] -1$$ Quantile Function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha )=\frac{\alpha \left[ \Phi ^{-1}\left( \frac{\tau +1}{2}\right) \right] ^{\frac{1}{\theta }}}{1+\alpha \left[ \Phi ^{-1}\left( \frac{ \tau +1}{2}\right) \right] ^{\frac{1}{\theta }}}$$ Reparametrization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )=\frac{\mu }{\left( 1-\mu \right) \left[ \Phi ^{-1}\left( \frac{\tau +1}{2}\right) \right] ^{\frac{1}{\theta }}}$$

title: The unit-Gompertz distribution — ugompertz
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\alpha \theta }{x}\exp \left\{ \alpha -\theta \log \left( y\right) -\alpha \exp \left[ -\theta \log \left( y\right) \right] \right\} $$ Cumulative density function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\exp \left[ \alpha \left( 1-y^{\theta }\right) \right] $$ Quantile Function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha ,\theta )=\left[ \frac{\alpha -\log \left( \tau \right) }{\alpha }\right] ^{-\frac{1}{\theta }} $$ Reparameterization $$\alpha =g^{-1}(\mu )=\frac{\log \left( \tau \right) }{1-\mu ^{\theta }}$$

title: The unit-Gumbel distribution — ugumbel
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\theta }{y(1-y)}\exp \left\{ -\alpha -\theta \log \left( \frac{y}{1-y}\right) -\exp \left[ -\alpha -\theta \log \left( \frac{y}{1-y}\right) \right] \right\}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid\alpha,\theta)={\exp }\left[ -{{\exp }}\left( -\alpha \right)\left( \frac{1-y}{y}\right) ^{\theta } \right] $$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha, \theta)= \frac{\left [-\frac{1}{\log(\tau)  }\right ]^{\frac{1}{\theta}}}{\exp\left ( \frac{\alpha}{\theta} \right )+\left [-\frac{1}{\log(\tau)  }\right ]^{\frac{1}{\theta}}}$$ Reparameterization $$\alpha =  g^{-1}(\mu ) =\theta \log \left( {\frac{1-\mu }{\mu }}\right) +\log \left( -\frac{1}{\log \left( \tau \right) }\right)$$ \(0<y<1\) \(\theta >0\) shape parameter.

title: The unit-Logistic distribution — ulogistic
text: Probability density function $$f(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\theta \exp \left( \alpha \right) \left(\frac{y}{1-y}\right) ^{\theta -1}}{\left[ 1+\exp \left( \alpha \right)\left( \frac{y}{1-y}\right) ^{\theta }\right] ^{2}}$$ Cumulative distribution function $$F(y\mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\exp \left( \alpha \right) \left( \frac{y}{1-y}\right) ^{\theta }}{1+\exp \left( \alpha \right) \left( \frac{y}{1-y}\right) ^{\theta }}$$ Quantile function $$Q(\tau \mid \alpha ,\theta )=\frac{\exp \left( -\frac{\alpha }{\theta }\right) \left( \frac{\tau }{1-\tau }\right) ^{\frac{1}{\theta }}}{1+\exp\left( -\frac{\alpha }{\theta }\right) \left( \frac{\tau }{1-\tau }\right) ^{ \frac{1}{\theta }}} $$ Reparameterization $$\alpha=g^{-1}(\mu )=\log \left( \frac{\tau }{1-\tau }\right) -\theta \log \left(   \frac{\mu }{1-\mu }\right) $$

 #> Compute Hessian approximation at finish of  BFGS  #> Compute gradient approximation at finish of  BFGS  #> Save results from method  BFGS  #> $par #> (Intercept)           x (Intercept)  #>   0.9971127   1.9125284   2.0537431  #>  #> $value #> [1] -140.6148 #>  #> $message #> NULL #>  #> $convcode #> [1] 0 #>  #> $fevals #> function  #>       29  #>  #> $gevals #> gradient  #>        9  #>  #> $nitns #> [1] NA #>  #> $kkt1 #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $kkt2 #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $xtimes #> user.self  #>     0.005  #>  #> Assemble the answers # Compare estimated coefficients cbind(gradient = coef(fit_gradient), no_gradient = coef(fit_nogradient)) #>              gradient no_gradient #> (Intercept) 0.9971136   0.9971127 #> x           1.9125274   1.9125284 #> theta       2.0537425   2.0537431

title: Parametric unit quantile regression models — unitquantreg
text: formula symbolic description quantile model like y ~ x y ~ x | z. See details. data data.frame contain variables model. subset optional vector specifying subset observations used fitting process. na.action function indicates happen data contain NAs. tau numeric vector. quantile(s) estimated, .e., number 0 1. just one quantile specified object class unitquantreg returned. numeric vector values 0 1 specified object class unitquantregs returned. See details. family character. Specify distribution family. link character. Specify link function quantile model. Currently supported logit, probit, cloglog cauchit. Default logit. link.theta character. Specify link function shape model. Currently supported identity, log sqrt. Default log. start numeric vector. optional vector starting values parameters. control list. Control arguments specified via unitquantreg.control. model logical. Indicates whether model frame included component returned value. x, y logical. TRUE corresponding components fit (model frame, response, model matrix) returned. unitquantreg.fit y numeric response vector values (0,1). X, Z numeric matrix. Regressor matrix quantile shape model, respectively. Default constant shape model, .e., Z matrix column ones.

title: Parametric unit quantile regression models — unitquantreg
text: unitquantreg can return object class unitquantreg tau scalar, .e., list following components. family distribution family name. coefficients list elements "quantile" "shape" containing coefficients respective models. fitted.values list elements "quantile" "shape" containing fitted parameters respective models. linear.predictors list elements "quantile" "shape" containing fitted linear predictors respective models. link list elements "quantile" "shape" containing link objects respective models. tau quantile specify. loglik log-likelihood fitted model. gradient gradient evaluate maximum likelihood estimates. vcov covariance matrix parameters model. nobs number observations. npar number parameters. df.residual residual degrees freedom fitted model. theta_const logical indicating \(\theta\) parameter treated nuisance parameter. control control parameters used fit model. iterations number iterations optimization method. converged logical, TRUE indicates successful convergence. kkt list logical  kkt1 kkt2 provide check Kuhn-Karush-Tucker conditions, first-order KKT test (kkt1) checks whether gradient final parameters estimates "small" second-order KKT test (kkte) checks whether Hessian final parameters estimates positive definite. elapsed_time time elapsed fit model. call original function call. formula original model formula. terms list elements "quantile", "shape" "full" containing terms objects respective models. model full model frame, model = TRUE. y response vector, y = TRUE. x list elements "quantile" "shape" containing model matrices respective models, x = TRUE. unitquantreg.fit returns unclassed list components elapsed_time. tau numeric vector length greater one object class unitquantregs returned, consist list objects class unitquantreg specified quantiles.

text: object1, object2 objects class unitquantreg containing fitted models. alternative indicates alternative hypothesis must one "two.sided" (default), "less", "greater". can specify just initial letter value, argument name must given full. See ‘Details’ meanings possible values.

text: list class "htest" containing following components: statistic value test statistic. p.value p-value test. alternative character string describing alternative hypothesis. method character string method used. data.name character string ginven name families models comparison.

title: Vuong test — vuong.test
text: statistic Vuong likelihood ratio test compare two non-nested regression models defined $$T = \frac{1}{\widehat{\omega}^2\,\sqrt{n}}\,\sum_{=1}^{n}\, \log\frac{f(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{ g(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i,\widehat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}})}$$ $$\widehat{\omega}^2 = \frac{1}{n}\,\sum_{=1}^{n}\,\left(\log \frac{f(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{g(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}})}\right)^2 - \left[\frac{1}{n}\,\sum_{=1}^{n}\,\left(\log \frac{f(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{ g(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}})}\right)\right]^2$$ estimator variance \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\,\displaystyle\sum_{=1}^{n}\,\log\frac{f(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{g(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}})}\), \(f(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\) \(g(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}})\) corresponding rival densities evaluated maximum likelihood estimates. \(n \rightarrow \infty\) \(T \rightarrow N(0, 1)\) distribution. Therefore, \(\alpha\%\) level significance  null hypothesis equivalence competing models rejected \(|T| > z_{\alpha/2}\), \(z_{\alpha/2}\) \(\alpha/2\) quantile standard normal distribution. practical terms, \(f(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\) better (worse) \(g(y_i \mid \boldsymbol{x}_i, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\gamma}})\) \(T>z_{\alpha/2}\) (\(T< -z_{\alpha/2}\)).

title: Vuong test — vuong.test
text: Vuong, Q. (1989). Likelihood ratio tests model selection non-nested hypotheses. Econometrica, 57(2), 307--333.

text: André F. B. Menezes Josmar Mazucheli

title: Vuong test — vuong.test
code: data(sim_bounded, package = "unitquantreg") sim_bounded_curr <- sim_bounded[sim_bounded$family == "uweibull", ]  fit_uweibull <- unitquantreg(formula = y1 ~ x, tau = 0.5,                              data = sim_bounded_curr,                              family = "uweibull") fit_kum <- unitquantreg(formula = y1 ~ x, tau = 0.5,                              data = sim_bounded_curr,                              family = "kum")  ans <- vuong.test(object1 = fit_uweibull, object2 = fit_kum) ans #>  #> 	Vuong likelihood ratio test for non-nested models (unit-Weibull versus #> 	Kumaraswamy) #>  #> data:  unit-Weibull versus Kumaraswamy #> T_LR = 3.9677, p-value = 7.258e-05 #>  str(ans) #> List of 4 #>  $ statistic: Named num 3.97 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "T_LR" #>  $ p.value  : Named num 7.26e-05 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "T_LR" #>  $ method   : chr "Vuong likelihood ratio test for non-nested models (unit-Weibull versus Kumaraswamy)" #>  $ data.name: chr "unit-Weibull versus Kumaraswamy" #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "htest"
